due to.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The court of inquiry ruled that the crash was due to pilot error.
She has been absent from work due to illness.
The restaurantâ€™s success was due largely to its new manager.
Attendance at the meeting was small, due in part to (=partly because of) the absence of teachers.
due to.translation[0].definitions[0].not: Due to is mostly used in formal or official contexts. In everyday English, people usually use because of:
We cancelled the picnic because of the weather.
